review_title: Generally good place to work but low pay
pros: I've mostly enjoyed my time at PATH. My colleagues are smart, kind, and easy to work with.
cons: As an early-mid career employee I've had increasing frustrations around compensation and growth opportunities. 1. While the pay is higher than other nonprofits, it is still too low. We have also taken pay cuts in the form of increased health insurance premiums over the past few years. 2. There are few opportunities for promotion and PATH has no structure for growing early career employees, whether they receive a promotion or not. I often get the feeling that I am falling behind my peers in other industries because there are not adequate avenues for skills development. This is likely a team dependent issue but it should be addressed at the organizational level. But it doesn't seem like there is appetite for this.

review_title: Great mission but not a great place to work.
pros: Noble mission to improve developing countries with equitable health care services and access. Well funded primarily by Gates foundation and other health grants. Pay is ok. good benefits.

New CEO is over his head. They hired the wrong person when they could have had a truly diverse and global leader experienced  in health. 

No job security. Lots of turn over as budgets shift, strategies changes, programs cut etc. Seattle office is basically being shut down as jobs move international. My guess 50% turnover a year.

The best people have left.

cons: Most of my interactions with staff are by email, and this is fine, but sometimes being able to speak with someone in the office would be nice. I've been told that this is in the works.

review_title: Most people seem happy there but it wasn't for me
pros:
-Good benefits (vision/dental/healthcare with reasonable contribution amounts/pet insurance available/401K
-Sense of teamwork
-Probably making a positive impact on the world
-People were kind and friendly day to day
-No one pressured me to work beyond my hours/scope; I'm not sure if that's universal but I saw a wide range of work/life boundaries
cons:
-Funding model causes sense of scarcity & and unnecessary urgency
-They could make many improvements on diversity of leadership staff
-I wasn't there long but I've heard internally that promotions were hard to come by - they don't have an enforced performance review schedule, you often have to ask for one, which isn't ideal; and in my experience, they are so casual it's not a great opportunity to ask for raises, etc.
-As a support staff member I often felt my time was disrespected by people with science/engineering roles. They were not rude but would refuse to learn how long in advance they need to make requests and expect admin/proofreading/etc staff to just get things done quickly to make up for their (engineer/chemistry/etc team's) lateness or lack of planning without apologizing or anticipating it's possible we would say no.

job_title: Technical Assistance Engineer in Patna, Bihar
pros: Can't think of any pros. Horrible experience at this organization.
cons:
1)No training given to freshers.
2) We were put into the work and no information was shared about HR functions of the company for first 10 days. Even after the first HR information session, we weren't made clear on whom to contact to get reimbursements for the business trips we made within first 10 days of work.
3) Working hours are 8 hrs on paper and working days 5, but from the first day job we worked overtime, even on non-working days, holidays and no overtime compensation was provided.
4) You'll be expected to complete the job and no resources, no team support would be provided. 
5) Zero coordination between various teams. 
6) Review meeting every week with the donor agency. Multiple meetings before the review meet with donor and that goes beyond working hours
7) Senior employees try to save themselves.
8) You'll be threatened sometimes to get the work done.
9) If you complain about female HR not helping you in getting your reimbursements, they might slap with you a sexual harrasment case.

pros: I love working at PATH. I love my team and I love the work we do. Pay and benefits are relatively excellent for the sector. I have been lucky to end up working under a manager that really values their employees both as contributors to the mission but also as individuals. My manager provides ample opportunities for professional development and is always mindful of work/life balance.
cons: Poor planning and misguided investments have led to serious overhead budget constraints and resulted in two significant rounds of layoffs this year alone. The general organizational "vibe" is pretty negative right now, and the highest levels of leadership are not doing much to inspire confidence in the organization. Paired with the current political environment, this overhead funding issue has resulted in PATH's inability to be flexible in adapting to the roller coaster that is government funding for programs.

review_title: Wait until senior leadership develops a strategy
pros: Programs are made up of smart, well-intended people.
cons: New leadership is out of touch and has made large restructuring efforts before developing a strategy or really understanding the organization. A multitude of partnerships are at risk and the PATH brand will be diluted. The best advice would be to wait a year or two until new, more capable leadership can put the organization back on track.

The ability to immerse oneself in a subject area beyond what a typical for profit entity would support.  A place to align your work with your values and support a worthy mission.
cons: PATH lacks a strong management philosophy which results in ambitious, passionate people being overloaded and unnecessarily stressed.  Lots of process inefficiencies that can be barriers to achieving impact.  Career growth is glacial resulting in lower level staff leaving and some returning later in their careers at a higher level.

pros:
Stimulating academic environment
Great human talent. The best co-workers I have ever had
Opportunity to be creative and explore your own path
No supervisors. You have performance leaders who help you with career goals, but you don't have a boss breathing down your neck.
Great international recognition. People love PATH's concept. They market themselves pretty well.
cons:
Although PATH is well funded, it is still an NGO and the challenges of working for a non profit also apply to PATH: everything depends on funding. Sometimes you end up doing what the donor wants you to do and not what is the best for people. Unfortunately the impact that PATH has made has not really been much. Not a lot of technologies have been introduced in the field.
Some departments need to be shaken up. Some people have been in the organization too long. New ideas would strengthen the organization.
HQ heavy. There are ~ 18 offices around the world, but HQ has the majority of employees. Funds sometimes stay in Seattle because there are too many people in HQ. Offices should have more independence and HQ should be there to support them and not the other way around.

pros: Offers her employees an opportunity to apply their skills in the global platform
cons: Not any known to me

review_title: 10+ years at PATH, 9 of them happy
pros: You are surrounded by some of the smartest, hardest-working, most accomplished professionals in the world of NGOs, public health, bio-tech and bio-medicine, and relevant supportive roles (admin, finance, PR/communications, etc.) The mission and history of the organization are inspiring, as is its legacy.
cons:
Leadership that does not lead. Unclear vision and direction. Extremely poor morale. Lack of support and appreciation for staff outside of executive team (8 or 9 people, vs global staff of 1200.) An "Emporer Has No Clothes" atmosphere, where rising to the top can only occur if you are a recent hire and/or a "Yes Man." 

There appears to be a pervasive belief at the top that PATH's past was problematic/unproductive/inefficient, that any accomplishments were accidental, and that only now might good things happen (eg, now that this gruop of leaders is in place.)

Consequently, it may be that the glory days of PATH are behind it, they seem to have lost their way, if not their soul. Many current and former staff find this quite sad.

review_title: Good organizational environment with many good resources for employees

review_title: Grant based employment - don't believe the long term "grant renewal process doesn't matter hype"
pros: This was one of the most family friendly environments I have ever worked in.  There a lots of creative people that work for this global organization.
cons: Unless you are working on a technology, or in country team, the organization itself does not know how to relate to others not in that specific field.  Recommendations, made by industry certified professionals are not taken very seriously.  I was hired in the middle of a 3 year GATES grant, which i was assured would be renewed and that the position would not be vulnerable to any reduction in force.  As my department went through the renewal process, they did the very thing they said they would not, eliminated positions due to the   grant renewal process.  In my opinion, jobs are only secure if you are at the beginning of a grant and for as long as the life of the grant.  In addition, the company is going through a restructuring and SEVERAL positions were eliminated, even those who were instrumental in making headway in new marketing areas.  Once the company has settled on a vision, mission statement and measurable goals, it may be a more secure place to work.

pros: Great brand / resume recognition & exposure to highly regarded NGOs and similar organization (e.g., Gates Foundation and WHO).  Travel to interesting places.  Very respectful of work / life balance.  Great place to work if you're a young parent with an MPH or MBA who doesn't think starting a family should come at the expense of having an interesting, self-actualizing job.  Helps if your spouse has a better paying job elsewhere.
cons: Passive-aggressive culture, slow work pace combined with false sense of urgency, pedantic bosses / coworkers combined with an oppressively "open," "innovative" culture that hasn't innovated much since the 1990s.  Pay sucks; no bonuses or profit-sharing benefits (duh, it's a non-profit), but you won't be destitute if you work at PATH and you do get an annual cost-of-living pay increase.  A lot of jockeying for scarce projects; long dry spells between interesting projects.  Most importantly, it's hard to advance at PATH, and "normal" 2- or 3-year promotions in the private sector (e.g., Technician or Analyst to Associate) take twice as long at PATH (e.g., low-level associate after 5 years).

pros: PATH is an excellent place to work if you are a mission driven individual.
cons: PATH could do a better job building career pathways for junior level staff.

pros:
Good salary package
Good leadership
Best working environment ever
Good relationship between senior management and staff
cons:
funding constraints specially from 2017
No guarantee of contract being renewed

pros: Great mission. Make a difference
cons: Work is increasingly consumed by funding challenges

pros: Team spirit and inclusion is commendable
cons: Short contract given to temporary staff

pros: Laid back and pretty casual
cons: Management doesn't listen to employee input

pros: Working towards being more country-centered leadership
cons: GPS system for getting and receiving feedback

review_title: Benefits are the only benefit here
pros: Great healthcare benefits, some commuter benefits
cons: Where do I begin? I read through some of the recent reviews, and they've hit the nail on the head. I've come across so many senior level staff who just cannot be bothered by anything or anyone other than themselves and what they can do to look better to their manager. This is unfortunate because there are so many staff members that really are star employees who genuinely care about the work they do. I generally like to think positively and give others the benefit of the doubt. But after a few years here, I've come to realize that the longer you stay here, the more toxic it is for your soul. I'm looking at you, "leadership". To those who are interested in PATH, just letting you know that other than senior level positions, there is high turnover here and it's not surprising.

review_title: Once a great organization that has lost its soul.
pros: Wonderful, smart colleagues; great mission.
cons: There has been tremendous change in the organization during the last two years, with a new CEO and a entirely new set of VPs (doubled in number by the CEO), very few of whom have any health or international development experience (about 1/2 are former Microsoft). It is as if only those with business/MBA backgrounds are valued-- that the previous leadership was somehow weak or undisciplined (not true.) Morale is extremely low these days-- with lay-offs and "belt-tightening" that seem to have been made necessary, in part, by the over-investment in high-priced but under-qualified VPs and heavy investment in PR. HR is not at all transparent. Public health as a core skill set is undervalued, with a number of staff with deep on-the-ground experience and public health expertise leaving or being laid off. Country programs are also being discounted-- viewed more as "platforms" for testing technologies than for forging long-term partnerships and shared leadership to advance health. Prevailing sense now that the HQ leadership "doesn't get it." A number of staff, especially those who have been at PATH for 10+ years, feel a profound sense of sadness about the direction the organization is taking.

review_title: Great organization with a few areas needing improvement.
pros:
-Very smart and driven technical and operations staff.
-This is one of the best places to find your own solutions to challenges in your line of work. 
-Some managers are great to work with and very supportive. Sadly they are becoming a dying breed.
-Great flexibility in working hours.
-Equality in use of office facilities i.e parking spaces, printers, kitchen
-Pay is competitive if coming from an outside organization.
Overall, your experience to a large extent is determined by your performance manager.
cons:
-Heavy top management that is averse to acting on feedback. 
-PATH prioritizes external applicants over internal ones with very poor chances of getting a good increment. 
-Lack of clear structures which cause duplication and lack of centralized information systems.
-Very limited sources of funding which makes PATH a great place where you come to get hands-on experience but leave immediately something better comes across.
-Unspoken inequality between Temporary and full-time staff in project offices.
-Wastage of money on unnecessary systems that are not critical to getting the job done. 
-HQ tendency to implement decisions that don't work in field office settings yet won't listen to feedback.

pros:
1. The mission is inspiring and you are contributing to work that really can make a difference.
2. Generous 401K company contribution
3. Decent vacation
cons: Extremely hierarchical. Morale varies by program and even by units within programs. And in many units, morale is really low. The leadership within certain programs is very top down, command and control. Senior leadership is comprised of many (not all) poor managers, some of whom are borderline abusive, many of whom are patronizing toward their staff. If you are working for one of these, you are on your own, so you must deal with it or get out. I think these less than stellar leadership team members are clueless about how little their staff respect them. They create a culture where blame always needs to be assigned. And it's never on them.  It's a bad sign when people walk around with a knot in their stomachs because they never know when they'll be blindsided.

review_title: An organization that has lost its focus
pros: Beautiful office space in a great part of town (South Lake Union) and quite a few great people who are passionate about global health.
cons: About 4 years ago PATH underwent a leadership change and at first there was transparent communication and logical steps to fine tune the structure of the organization, but then the strategic vision started to get muddy. Senior managers were brought in that either had no global health experience or were horrid managers. PATH leadership did not communicate to either the staff or the public what was going on, and over the course of a couple of years a huge group of PATH employees left. Many of these employees had been with the organization for decades and had helped to build PATH's reputation. All of this might make sense if there was a different strategic vision and if there had been a well crafted turn around plan to bring PATH towards a more market driven focus, but that is not the case. The best commercialization officers left the organization as well and each month it seems that things are getting worse.

job_title: Associate Director, Management in Seattle, WA
pros:
Mission is powerful and the organization has a positive impact on the communities it serves.  The organization is undergoing change in an effort to be competitive with other NGOs and work more effectively across the organization.  In my area this has meant a lot of changes in leadership, including changes in managers/performance leaders.
The organization is trying to proactively manage this change, but it is hard and can feel chaotic.  The project work continues to move forward and I do think our leaders are trying to improve things and prepare for the future.
cons: Reorganizations take a long time (actually decision making and change in general is slow) and the systems are archaic, so months can go by between an announcement and action.  Given the fast-paced environment of the project work, this creates a strange environment.  Leadership is often not aware of the impact that additional reviews/committees have on the teams, particularly given the relatively heavy involvement of the donors in much of our work.

pros: I loved my time at PATH and learned so much about PATH's mission and projects as an international NGO. I had great supervisors that really cared about my professional development, interests, and career goals. The work environment is casual and positive with a beautiful office space, fun events, and coffee, tea, and cookies always on hand.
cons: Interns are paid very low wages (although it is nice to be paid at all as an intern!) and do not receive any benefits. There is also a bit of a disconnect between interns/temps and employees that is frustrating long-term. After interning for over six months I still could not have a key card to enter the building, be on the "staff" email list-serv, or use the staff wifi.

pros: People who work there are awesome and have unique personalities. The work is interesting depending on the project you work on.
cons: Extremely inefficient leadership. The CEO starts off new projects without really thinking through the implications or timelines. Most of the executive team does not have the experience in leading people and are simply there waiting for retirement. It is surprising how country leaders still manage to accomplish what they are despite the inefficiency in the Seattle office.

pros: The program in which you work dictates your experience. I worked in a great program with wonderful colleagues that were very supportive. I was provided true supervision (i.e. mentorship, support, and good critical feedback) and was given meaningful work that helped further grow my skill set. The pay and benefits were good.
cons: During my time at PATH, Program Assistants and the work they did wasn't valued as much as other staff. There wasn't a clear career path for Program Assistants to move up in the organization and from recent review there still isn't. Turnover of staff at all levels was a regular occurrence.

review_title: Great place to work. Varied experience by Program
pros: Flexible work environment. Able to work on projects that make a real impact in the world. Great benefits including access to learning resources. As a young professional, you may be eligible for what's called the "Opportunities for New Professionals (ONP)" award. This allows you to work and possibly travel with other PATH programs to grow professionally and learn more about what PATH does.
cons:
The employee experience is HIGHLY variable and really depends on your Program and specifically you Performance Leader (supervisor). Some people have a great relationship with their PL and work in a Program they are personally interested in, while others have the exact opposite experience. 

When you interview, be sure to ask about the office culture, lines of communication and authority, expectations of someone in your role and how your role clearly fits into the overall organizational structure.

review_title: A total disaster of an organization, with mean-spirited officers
pros: They always have extra food around?
cons:
If you are on a bad project, your life will be ruined. Many people in this organization are nice, but there is a bigger portion of folks that are mean-spirited, nasty, and will actually go out of their way to gossip or openly sabotage junior staff if they have a personal problem with them. The other PAs I spoke to echoed the idea that they couldn't recommend this position to anyone, and that's exactly how I feel. 

Senior management doesn't care about mean-spirited employees, and everyone is aware of the  gossip, catty culture that exists, but they don't care. Every day was painful. 

The pay is awful and the benefits are only okay, which is unfortunate for a global health organization. The family leave policy is horrible, which is disappointing given the focus on maternal health. There's no end goal in sight for a lot of the programs, meaning we were left to just focus on small goals instead of driving real impact.

pros: Nice office and good compensation.
cons: There is very little accountability at all levels of the organization, a lack of true strategy, an inability or unwillingness to ask and answer hard questions, poor internal communication, and a very high turnover rate of people in senior leadership positions. These, among other factors, contribute to a very inefficient and unproductive atmosphere, making it incredibly difficult to get good work done at PATH. On top of this, the culture is truly toxic. Per other reviews, bullying and 'mean girl' antics are rampant. The word 'difficult' is thrown about regularly to discredit people, particularly female colleagues. Many incredibly talented and productive colleagues get forced out of PATH in this way. Reputations at PATH can be made or broken with a few choice words. Actual work produced or business generated have little to no influence on a person's reputation at PATH since the organization doesn't place much value on productivity. It is not surprising that this 'mean girl' culture is rampant at PATH given the lack of strong leadership and inadequate/nonexistent systems of accountability.

review_title: Take a look at how they treat their inferiors
pros:
•	Legacy institution
•	Some of the most amazing people
•	Good workplace diversity - lots of women and people of color
•	Work-life balance, lots of vacation and sick days
•	Good connections
cons:
•	Very prejudiced against “non-technical” staff, junior staff, temps, interns
•	Limited career growth opportunities 
•	Centralized services are underfunded, have no review mechanisms, and introduce unnecessary inefficiencies 
•	Passive aggressive culture
•	Senior management actively discourages innovation and novel ideas from lower-level staff
•	No feedback mechanisms for management 
•	Lots of donor funds invested in communications and leadership projects with little oversight and questionable impact

I write this review with quite a lot of reservation. I have a lot of respect for PATH as a legacy global health institution with historical knowledge matched by few other organizations. But unfortunately, what remains of this legacy is bogged down but what I’ll simply call willful ignorance. 

Most work I’ve observed has been unsuccessful by most measures, and management appears willfully ignorant. Timelines are routinely delayed for fixable reasons, Sharepoint is considered a cutting edge project management tool, significant investments are funneled into a mediocre digital presence, document production is mired in endless reviews, and an over-zealous proofreading culture makes writing anything much more difficult than it needs to be (PATH takes pride in having their own internal editorial style—which is just as ridiculous as it sounds: most companies are content using international standards, like Chicago style or AMA)—the list of incompetencies goes on. 

On some level this is to be expected: nonprofits can’t invest in centralized processes like other international firms. The traditional donor model struggles to scale. 

However, the most perplexing part of PATH is how the organization appears to operationalize willful ignorance of inefficient systems. You could tell management “no” many times and provide clear feedback on ways to improve—and all of it appears to go nowhere. And this happens with external groups as well: I’ve seen donors provide clear directives like, “the sample size of your study is too small,” only to see similar studies with the same sample size designed months later. 

From the perspective of a junior staff, I think this ignorance comes from prejudice: many “senior” staff have advanced technical degrees and probably believe on some level their education gives them expert authority. In a true culture of "innovation," ideas would be privileged over experience. Everyone matters because everyone potentially has innovative ideas. But at PATH, the ideas that seem to matter are the ideas from tenured “technical” staff. If you don’t appear to have the right expertise, the expectation is to bob your head in meetings, signaling quiet optimism and passive agreement with a smile. I’ve seen PAs with global health degrees asked to do nothing but process documents and spend hours of labor on Sharepoint sites. I've seen qualified, smart internal candidates with Master’s degrees denied promotions in favor of inexperienced candidates with “technical” Bachelor’s degrees in Biology/Chemistry/Engineering. I’ve seen “technical" staff quickly promoted to “Senior” level titles for no apparent reason. Meanwhile, some of the most motivated employees, with novel and interesting perspectives, are asked to sit quietly, take meeting minutes, and keep calendars for the “technical" project officers they support. Like it’s said in Harry Potter: “If you want to know what a man’s like, take a good look at how he treats his inferiors, not his equals.”

pros: Strong and impactful history of providing vaccines and medical device technology to low income countries.  Grantee of Gates Foundation with lengthy and strong relationship which is one reason USG and WHO partner.  Consulting type firm environment for short term projects.
cons:
Difficult to reach staff and management up the chain, can be cliquish and stifles innovation due to lack of open communication.  Country offices run mostly on their own with little oversight by HQ.   Following ethics policies not clear, staff coming in can be treated poorly by country leadership and their staff with no repercusion.  
McKinsey type of operation at HQ, does not work well with running a long term project. Lots of MBA types.

review_title: PATH does mediocre work, is dragged down by lack of technical skills
pros: Track record of developing innovative products for health. Great work environment, benefits, 9-5 culture.
cons: Many people here are on cruise control, doing minimal work with no ability or incentive to progress in the organization and produce better work. Management if often unskilled and from unscientific backgrounds and unable to acquire, develop, or keep highly talented folks with cutting edge skills.  Relatively anti-social work place, few opportunities to meet people within the organization.

pros:
Flexible work schedule
Opportunities for independent work and management
Interesting projects
cons:
Senior leadership is a joke, more concerned with vanity projects and money-grubbing than actually demonstrating true value
Leadership in general is lacking, terrible management skills from majority of project directors, some are downright hostile to employees yet get away with it because they are 'experts' in their field
No room for growth or advancement, period, unless you are willing to scheme and backstab
Junior and middle-level staff treated as disposable

review_title: Don't expect this place to launch your career- make sure you come in at the correct level and salary
pros: Great work, great reputation in the industry, work/life balance, location! I am hopeful that the new CEO will turn this place around (the McKinsey consultants were on board on his first day I think...) but it's going to take a few years to feel the results.
cons: Employee career paths, development and retention; 1200 person org with some very outdated systems and processes

pros: PATH does a lot of amazing work, the mission is inspiring, many talented employees and leaders in the organization.   The location is great and the office in Seattle is very nice.   Satisfaction can vary depending on your manager - my manager is excellent and I have been very happy working at PATH.
cons: Donor-funded environment means there is always risk of funding or program cuts. Benefits can be pricey if covering dependents.  There has been a lot of change and turnover on the leadership team.  PATH is a non-profit , and the pay is lower than what you'll find at other companies in the area.

review_title: Non-profit mentality is not for everyone.
pros: Great new facilities. Somewhat flexible in hours, depending on department. Many great projects making healthcare more accessible around the world. Decent benefits package. Opportunities to keep informed about company's projects. Diverse and well educated staff.
cons: Environment plagued by long term employees not willing to change. Many inefficiencies cause a lot of unnecessary and duplicate work. Pay is below market for most mid to lower level jobs, but that is normal in the non-profit world. No well developed management structure. Grant monies restrict posibility for bonuses and pay increases.

pros:
Good benefits, including retirement match and vision insurance
Some great people that are both knowledgeable and passionate about the work
cons:
Oh dear- where to start? I guess at the top- The Executive team only has 1 woman and 1 person with experience at another organization working in international development. None have worked for another non-profit, but all are "passionate about the mission"- it would be great to have people that are also experienced in non-profit management.
The company is very Seattle-focused. If you are not in Seattle (where the entire Executive team is based), then it will be difficult to inspire improvements or change.

job_title: Senior Program Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: Pays well and has decent benefits.
cons:
- Leadership/management lacks the ability to scrutinize itself and address the many issues it is currently facing. Leadership is unable to introspect and growing discontent is viewed as 'noise' 
- Very limited accountability within the organization. 
- Limited managerial capacity and associated capacity to leverage the capabilities of employees. Filling up with  'very important people' who do not often meet the urgent requirements for a role. 
- As mentioned by many reviewers earlier - 'mean girl' culture is pervasive. Many 'senior staff' spend more time on political maneuvering rather than creating value and focusing on the work
- Top down/command-control culture. There is limited communication on a need to know basis  from senior management to the rest of the organization. 
- Fancy mission but not translated to action

review_title: Building a better world with amazing colleagues
pros:
The quality of talent at this organization is astounding.  So many dedicated, compassionate, smart, and resourceful individuals pulling together for a collective cause much larger than themselves.  Very refreshing to see in this day and age.

Compensation is very competitive, especially for certain roles.  In keeping with their ethos, the benefits are off the charts.  There's a very heavy focus on the people aspects of the business, which often results in a good work-life balance.
cons: Not always a clear path for career advancement, but if you're willing to be creative and carve out a niche, the right opportunities can occasionally come up.

review_title: PATH offers a great learning environment but lacks opportunities for career advancement.
pros: Very talented, passionate people. Staff is very understandable and flexible to personal schedules and need to work around working hours. Work-life balance is definitely encouraged. Benefits are great although pay could be better. Higher-level staff enjoy a more rewarding experience at PATH. HQ is located in a comfortable building near many bus lines and amenities.
cons:
Many systems within in PATH are just redundant and inefficient. Efforts to streamline often make processes more convoluted – very frustrating! While many individual staff are supportive of career development, there are very few, if any, opportunities for this. The “Opportunities for New Professionals” award has been eliminated with the expansion of the executive team. And without support from your performance leader/program leader, training that is available may not be available to you. 

Your experience is largely shaped by the program(s) team you are a part of. There are some long-term folks at PATH now serving as program leads and directors – while it is great to have management that has seen PATH through its many phases, they often bring an outdated mentality that does not help “lower level” employees advance or even feel heard. My role on the programs I support and contribute to vary widely; with one group holding me to their hierarchical view of how things should work and with other groups allowing me to use my skill-set at the associate level. This is very discouraging as many program assistants at PATH come in very over qualified yet trapped in this bottleneck that does not allow for advancement. Getting a promotion is practically a lost cause, no matter how much enthusiasm you bring. As far as the admin positions go; PATH hires for the position, not the person. 

I often feel underutilized and disengaged – and this is certainly not an attribute of my character. When I have expressed interest in training opportunities or wanting to take on more responsibility, I am generally met with encouragement and support. However, when the opportunities present themselves to make this real, I am met with push-back and discouragement in doing so. I am not engaged and often deterred from contributing to any meaningful work making my day-to-day quite boring and very frustrating. Program assistants come through PATH in a revolving door, my time here is now headed out.  

I would recommend PATH to a friend to gain exposure to public health programming but not for a long-term career or for advancement opportunities (unless you are career admin and not working to advance into more direct public health work). 

-Hierarchical
-Bureaucratic
-Pay scale
-No avenue for advancement (even among qualified individuals)

review_title: Great organization, great people, lots of change
pros:
World-class nonprofit.
Incredible mission and dedicated staff.
Smart, well adjusted coworkers in many areas throughout the organization.
Well resourced for a nonprofit.
History of thoughtful leadership.
Pretty family friendly.
cons: Growth and change, including a new president and top executives, are creating a lot of upheaval throughout the organization. There's a desire by new leadership to "take it to the next level," but little recognition of the hard and excellent work that has brought the organization to this point.

pros: A global non profit with focus on improving health for all, and specifically women and children. PATH presents itself as an innovative, dynamic organization with offices in over 70 countries. If you want to contribute to a good cause, PATH's mission and vision will speak to you.
cons: Head-count of C-level leadership almost doubled in past 2 years with unclear results. Poor internal communication, silos, oppressive work climate. Being innovative appears to be more of a marketing strategy. Organizational structure and culture does not reflect "innovation".

pros: Though each experience is team specific, the people I work with are incredibly smart and fantastic coworkers. The managers are open and give good feedback, and the team is able to depend on each other. Great benefits
cons: As is common with program specific work, you don't often get an opportunity to work with or even interact with people outside the program. Career pathway isn't clear for early career employees.

review_title: Great experience and resume builder, limited growth potential
pros:
Great mission and wonderful, driven people
Opportunities to learn about many aspects of the public health sector--grant writing, budget management, communications, reporting
High salary and good benefits, compared to entry-level positions at other INGOs
Partnerships with other organizations
Great reputation; it has looked great for me since
Transparency
Team spirit
cons: Very little growth opportunity for Program Assistants--most come to build their resume and experience, and then leave for for grad school or another organization with better growth potential within 1-3 years.

pros: Good location. Company has good values (if only they were better about communication internally).
cons:
Terrible benefits for a healthcare company. With Cigna it is almost impossible to find a healthcare provider. 
Leadership is unorganized and unaligned. Employees hoard information. Layoffs almost every year make you fear for your job. A lot of employees with families always leaving early and working from home. Difficult to move around in the company. Raise at year end is NOT based on performance but a very small flat rate. Values of the company are great but culture is lacking seriously.

review_title: Fantastic, if occasionally frustrating place to work!
pros: The mission and the people can't be beat. The variety of projects is immense, so there's a lot to do and never a dull day. My team members were smart, kind, passionate folks. For a non-profit, the support for administration is better than many, so important functions like accounting, procurement, and library services work well. Many organizations neglect these departments to their detriment. Leadership was changing as I left, but seemed positive. Work-life balance, benefits, pay, and facilities were excellent.
cons: While many individual staff are supportive, there were very few, if any, opportunities for career advancement. Senior management would preach about how important it was to stay up to date and then completely ignore any efforts staff made to actually improve themselves. Unless you left for an expensive graduate degree so you could continue to do the job you were already doing, that is. Everyone wants to work here, so I understand that they don't technically have to invest in their employees' careers, but PATH is seriously losing great people at every level of the organization, particularly the lower ones. Great bosses abound and make up for a lot of this, but the attitude from leadership at the time was that you and your goals were unimportant unless you were a director or something. They do work to protect lower-level staff when grants dry up, which is nice, but there is very little formal acknowledgment of the important work they do.

job_title: Senior Program Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Knowledgeable and friendly HR staff
- Professional and timely follow-up calls and emails
- Commitment to valuing the candidate and providing an inspiring experience
- Easily the most efficient and thoughtful interactions with HR staff that I encountered during my job search
cons:
- If you are passionate about global health, PATH is the best organization in the world to work for
- I have only admiration and respect for PATH

pros:
-The benefits (total compensation package) are great compared to other global health groups in the area outside of Gates.
-Depending on project, lots of opportunities to grow.
-Wonderful colleagues in the field
cons:
I worked for PATH for almost a decade.  My first 7 years were great and my last 2 were awful.  It has taken me almost 2 years to be able to not be bitter about my time there in general.  I worked on a wonderful program with lots of growth, travel and learning.  Then new leadership came in, and new staff, and they lost their way.  For the new staff, it was all about us vs. them.  They didn't respect teams in the field, they lack all the soft skills needed to do the work, and they were more interested in internal networking.  I spent most of my last few years putting out fires between old and new staff than actually doing the job I was hired to do.  

Also, besides ignoring the interpersonal issues, PATH leadership is literally running after every dollar they can find, even if there have no real expertise in that work or don't believe in it.  

Lastly, the internal promotion process is horrible.  I was told that while I was eligible for a raise, it couldn't be a promotion and had to be limited to just 5% even though I was doing work about my pay level.  I was actually told by an HRBP that if they replaced me, they would have to pay the new position (at a higher level) almost 20% more. I was floored that they didn't want to retain current staff they had invested in.  Less than a year after I left, I was recruited for a more senior position and offered almost 25% more than what I made when I left.  I didn't feel I was qualified for the position, and didn't want to travel so much, so I declined to be considered.  The situation showed how much they value internal growth.

pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my time working at PATH. I only left to be a stay at home mom and even went back multiple times when my schedule allowed for some flexibility. I would recommend the organization to anyone looking to work for a non profit that does tangible work and makes a real difference in the world.
cons: During my time there was a shakeup in management, which wasn't much fun, but seems to be more stable now.

review_title: Could be better, could be worse.
pros:
- Awesome benefits
- Depending on your team, can have awesome and nurturing coworkers
- Training opportunities (if your project has funding to cover them)
- Pleasant office envorinment
cons:
- Very, very difficult to get promotions/raises, even when you work overtime on assignments way above your pay grade. High staff turnover is not surprising.
- Growth (both personal/professional and organizational) is heavily restricted by project funding (or lack thereof).
- Senior management are experts in their technical fields but often lack managerial/leadership skills..

review_title: Huge potential, but what a mess
pros: Exposure to all of the big non-profits and foundations, opportunity to work on world-changing projects with some of the smartest people in their fields in the world, pretty high paying for a non-profit, some travel to far-flung locales
cons: No accountability, no vision or direction from management, silo projects don't allow cross-org collaboration, donor funding determines all opportunities, might as well be a contractor for the Gates Foundation, employee morale is the pits, benefits are so-so

review_title: A great community of wonderful people
pros: PATH fosters a community of warm, intelligent and enthusiastic people who are deeply committed to making the world a better place. Without the ego of other global health/development organizations, I found the environment at PATH to be heavily collaborative and supportive, with wonderful mentorship opportunities for interns. In addition to the warm community, the work life balance is great! Can't say enough good things about my time there.
cons: Sometimes temps get the short end of the stick; career advancement opportunities/ continuous employment can be tricky when jobs are tied to grant funding

pros: Great people, complex but important work. Good benefits. In general very good people to work with, people focused on mission not climbing ladder.
cons: Somewhat ambiguous reporting structure. High work load almost to the point of ridiculousness, they over load work not on intention but because of grant structure. You are billed a certain percentage to project but many people have four projects at 25% and each project works you much more than allotted time.

pros: Interesting work, great people, ability to work with people from other cultures, participate in ground-breaking public health interventions.
cons: Reporting requirements can be onerous. Systems are generally in disarray.  Many projects stopped and started with little to no explanation.

pros:
Lots of work in the healthcare industry, fascinating stuff that you can get involved with which has a positive effect on those in need across India and beyond. Plenty of opportunities to work in different fields owing to the diverse undergoing projects at PATH India. 
Unparalleled professionalism, beautiful office and some great colleagues. Yearly bonus plus excellent salary and benefits
cons: None at all,  office is in Connaught Place so maybe if anyone's coming from far away it's a con ( but that's not really a con, just Delhi logistics )

review_title: Nice place to work; faults in senior management of programs
pros: informal dress; diverse people from all over the world; a good mission to strive for; nice headquarters; pays well for an NGO;
cons: Some programs are going down; this is brought on by bad senior management and the executive management being split too thin and not able to properly manage the senior management of the spearate programs.

pros: Autonomous work style. Many opportunities to get involved and hands on work. Opportunity to impact others across the globe and give back in a meaningful way.
cons: I would guess it's the same with most non profit orgs...resources are spread thin and funds are scarce. If comparing pay alone to for profit companies there is a difference of about 20%. If you are not in a place where you can sacrifice pay, I would not recommend PATH.

pros: The company gives attention to its staff welfare and wellbeing with an annual review of benefits.  PATH has an eye for competitive staff in relation to peers.
cons: PATH pays staff in wide salary ranges,  this means that you can attract low skilled workers to work for senior positions as long as they fall within your salary ranges. Senior members on one part could feel unappreciated.

review_title: PATH is a great place to work, but reliance on donor funding limits its potential.
pros: Smart, humble staff and a great team environment.  Beautiful building.
cons: Donor-driven environment. Donors often call the shots, leaving little opportunity for innovative activity outside of what is defined under our grants. Unclear growth trajectory for most staff. Not enough leadership hiring done from within the ranks (over-reliance on outside hires).

pros: Great mission, co-workers, benefits, and positive work atmosphere. PATH is a well-respected leader in the global health sphere, and it has an interesting portfolio of work.
cons: Very little attention is paid to entry-level staff and their professional development. The programs and departments are highly segregated in their work, with little interaction between them. The organization can feel too corporate at times.

review_title: Not suitable place for technocrats, good for people managing govt. relations only

review_title: A solid organization that does superb work in the field but does a poor job engaging junior and mid-level staff.

cons: Bureaucratic; little acknowledgement for progress and success in work; does not inspire creativity; little room for growth and promotions.

pros: PATH is very professional and has one of the best reputations in the global health field. They work really hard on trying to address global health issues in new and innovative ways and are always collaborating with other sectors and institutions to achieve its mission.

job_title: Senior Program Assistant in Atlanta, GA

Name recognition in global health
If you get on the right team, you may learn something valuable & transferrable
cons:
Management...and that term is used loosely. It was evident that seniority is all that matters at PATH. You have PLs that have been with the organization for years and still have no clue about managing personnel, performance management or leadership, It really is a joke. 

Suggestion: Get in so you can have them on your resume and then run!!! Not like they will mind anyway. Organizational culture is horrible.

pros: Great people, great mission, management seems committed to finding their way in a shifting funding environment, but it's more corporate than it used to be. It's a time of culture shift.
cons: Organization in big transition with some growing pains.

job_title: Senior Commercialization Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: PATH is staffed with great people and they foster a truly collaborative environment. They also offer some of the most interesting projects and show a strong commitment to innovation.  While salary is not great given your experience, their benefits are strong.
cons: Like most NGOs there is a lot of bureaucracy.  The back office at PATH is some of the worst I have seen in terms of cumbersome processes, slow response times and expensive internal support.
